Not anisey like the Abt (sampled side-by-side) - but slightly more sour and bitter, leaning towards the Grottenbier.
([email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ 2007, Essen, way too cold) Slightly hazy reddish brown with a smallish, lacy head. Dried fruit in the aroma with caramel and grainy malt. Flavor is much like Abt, but with more malt sweetness. Medium-bodied, slightly sticky palate with low carbonation. Nice. Bottle rating coming up...

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2009 2007. Good Looking muddy brown brew with a slight orange tinge. Head pours large and stays pretty well. Head is an off-white tan in color, creamy smooth in texture, and has nice lacing. Aroma is complex with citrus hoppy-ness coming through. Allspice and a light yeasty-dough aroma , followed by many other smells including chocolate, apple, and possibly even red wine. Flavor was pleasant, starting on the sweetish side and over a long duration finishing ever so slightly bitter-sour with defined fruit undertones. Medium in body with a lively carbonated but creamy texture, the overall mouth feel is clearly the best part of this brew. Pretty good stuff.

750 ml bottle shared by highibus - Pours a slightly hazy deep amber color with a large off white head.  Aroma is esters(banana), spice, and light yeast.  Flavor is basicly the same with some light bready malt coming through.  Medium body.  A good beer.  Thanks Tom.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2008 Pours a dark brown color with garnet highlights and a beige, full, rocky, fluffy head which diminishes quickly to a average, creamy, lasting layer leaving some nice lace.  Nose is certainly rich for the season with some Belgian chocolates, apple pie, nutmeg, clove, light hazlenut, and a touch of earthy hops.  Flavor is certainly similarly rich; initial flavors include cooked apples, cinnamon, nutmeg, and clove, almost like spicy apple sauce.  Then the malts come in with lots of Belgian chocolates, faint roast, light date, and light molasses; by the finish a decent earthy hop presence settles in with some hazlenut.  Palate is medium-full, lively, and velvety with only a hint at some warmth in the finish.  By the finish, the spices diminish some, the chocolates linger along with the date and nutty notes, and the earthy bitterness and warming notes round out the long finish.  Actually a pretty nice Christmas beer with a rich malt apalte and nice spicing to back it up.  A bit too much carbonation and a tad thin too fit into the great Belgian category, but it is a fitting beer for the season.  Maybe it was put out a bit early and would benefit from some aging, but still a nice new offering from the brewery.
750 ml bottle.  Purchased at Hamiltons.   Dark brown pour, peppery aroma.  Flavor is fruity, spicy and slightly hoppy.  A little to peppery for my tastes, but pretty good.
Courtesy of Mcbackus. Pours a dark brown with a off white foamy head. Lacing is great throughout session. Has hints of spice, dark fruit, yeast, pepper, and caramel. Finishes sweet and bubbly.

750 mL bottle purchased at Liquor Max in Loveland, CO.  Poured into my newly acquired tulip glass.  Pours deep, rich mahogany with a huge, frothy, rocky, light brown head, mostly lasting with excellent lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (bread, cookie, caramel, nutty), average hops (grass), average yeast (earth, musty) with notes of plum, baked apples, and brown sugar.  Full bodied, creamy and fizzy texture, lively carbonation, and a slightly spicy and bitter finish.  Average duration, moderate sweetness and acidity, light bitterness.

750ml bottle @ Hams, purchased for the table by Naven, shared with Naven and Bartzilla.  Pours dark reddish brown with a 1 finger tan head.  Aroma is spicy and spiced with a heavy dose of pepper.  Taste is peppery, and a damn nice belgian strong taste.  Usually am not a fan of this kind of spice but it worked here.
Bottle @ a Christmas party.  Very sweet and overdone w/ spices.  Dont like spiced brews and didnt like this one.

Thanks to El Gordo for this one--Poured a deep black-brown body with small whitish head.  Nose of grapefruit, brown sugar, molasses, and dark fruits.  Roasty, complex and quite scrumptious.  Warm, smooth, and dry finish.  Very nice!
Almost black coloured beer with a small off white head. Full malty ripe fruity roasted aroma. Creamy palate. Finish is bitter malty with some roasted little alcoholic touches.

Flaske. Sidste år og i år ved siden af hinanden. Super lækker sidste år, rund og afbalanceret med kraftige toner af lakrids. Disse noter er der slet ike i års, som er meget mere frisk og med et bid i der ikke er i den anden. Men begge øl en udsøgt glæde at drikke.

On tap, yesterday @ Kerstbierfestival.
Almost black color, with beige creamy  head. Aroma roasted malts, fruits, spices. Medium tot full body.  Taste = very sweet, roasted malts, warming alcoholic touch. Dry end. Nice.
Pours amber into a trappist glass.  Medium to large sized head recedes at a medium pace to skim surface.  Nutmeg aromas.  Pit fruit and spices.

From Plaza Liquors.  Pours a beautiful mahogany color.  Great spicy and estery aroma.  First pour was very foamy.  Did settle nicely though.  Nice christmas flavor, but it was a little thin.  Hid the alcohol content well.  Not the best belgian I have had but a nice beer.

Big bottle at Stone Brewery.Thin white head on top of murky brown. Good yeasty fruity smell. Fair bit of carbonation on the palate. Tastes of sweet malt, dried plum, and fig. Not real robust and full as the 12.

From bottle at Zenos. Light spicy aroma. Horse blanket and light spicy hoppiness. A mild sour tang. Dark copper-amberclear with foamy lacing light-tan head. Medium waery body with medium carbonation. Starts with dull sweetness, good malt and a touch of hoppiness. Floral spicy note, with light toffee sweetnes and a bit of dry nutty bitter in the finish.  Mild fruity finish and cherry woody after.
Bottle. Dark amber colour with a beautiful off-white head. Aroma and flavour of spice, dark fruits, caramel, hops and malt.

Deep amber, very nice head, very attractive.  Aroma is bready with some dark fruits, undefined spice in the background, and a touch of alcohol.  Flavor is malty sweet with plum fruit, ginger, cinnamon, and a hint of clove.  Christmas focused without overwhelming the beer itself.  Finish has a note of vanilla.  Not bad.  Not crazy about the spicing, but not bad.

Dark mahogany pour, big almond head. Aroma is fruity with holiday spices as well with spicy belgian yeast. Flavor is much the same, fruity malts, some caramel, a touch of chocolate but lots of holiday type spices from the yeast. Very complex and hard to describe but the yeast is the flavor, fruity, malty, some chocolate and roasted notes but lots of dark fruits and caramel.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2014 Bottle (2014). Head is initially large, frothy, light brown, fully lasting. Body is dark amber-brown. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (cookie, toasted grain), lightly yeasty (dough, basement), with light notes of clove, sassafras, cinnamon, anise, candy sugar. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery/velvety texture, lively carbonation, moderately to heavily alcoholic.

Rather watery and simple.  The nose has a reasonably nice spice blend but overall theres just not much aroma at all. Kinda watery and burning in the mouth. Not bad, but seems phoned in.

Dark brown, thick creamy tan head.    Soft fruity aromas of ripe plum and cherry that sit on spiced vanilla brown sugar tones.  Dried fruit flavor is well balanced by yeasty sugary caramel notes and hints of rounding hop bitterness.  Medium to full bodied, moderate carbonation, spiced dark fruit finish.  A nice winter warmer without a doubt.  Thanks for sharing, Brian!

750mL, 10%ABV.  Dark haze, medium brown, Fizzy head.  Aroma of yeast, malts, some cherry essence.  Flavor is malt.  Hollow mouthfeel.  Empty body.  Odd.  Fizzy texture on the palate.  Hints of dark fruits in the finish.  Yeasty flavors left on the palate.
Mahogany pour with a fluffy off white head that lasted for a while. Nice lacing. Aromas of dark ripe fruits, plums, and hints of caramel. Bitter to sweet with lots of malty sweetness. Medium bodied.
bottle, tasty beer. Couldnt tell this had 10% alcohol. Poued a reddish color. Spicy and malty. hides its strong alcohol with so many diffrent flavors. This was quite good.

Deep brown, reddish-tinted beer wth a lively head and the cheeriest bottle of the season.  Fruity, delicious aromas of figs, pit fruit, coriander, ginger and other spices, and caramel malts.  Impressive palate; light, slick, but with rich flavors and a dry finish that maintains its cherry fruit and slight effervescence.  Tastes of caramel, figs, plums, coriander, candied nuts and fruit.

This reminds me of the Grottenbier.  Full bodied and loaded with malt.  Good, thick palate, tall thick head.  Very sticky and sweet.  The aroma has fruit and malt, flavor more of the same.  Some coriander, plums.

Huge beige fluffy head over a hazy dark brown body.  Mostly sweet aroma of christmas spice, banana.  Taste is similarly sweet with some banana, clove, fig.  Pretty smooth mouthfeel from the carbonation.  Alcohol definitely shows especially as it warms.  Not as complex as I had hoped.

Pours a dark ruby/ chestnut brown with thick, slightly beige head.  Pleasant aroma consisting of cherries, dark fruits, chocolate, cinnamon spice and alcohol.  Very smooth drinking and surprising amount of fruit.  Cherries, plum, sugar cane, dark berries and peppery cinnamon taste.  Dry finish with a nice alcohol warmth.  A very nice balance of maltiness, spiciness, fruit and alcohol.  Very tasty!
Poured a nice dark brown.The nose was sweet with alcohol pushing through.Flavor was caramel sweetness with some dark fruits making an apperance.It was a nice warming beer to finish.
Murky brown color with a large head.  Strong aroma of yeast, spice, banana and cinnamon.  The first taste that jumped to mind was spearmint.  Very herbal.  Malty and yeasty.  And tasty!

Deep ruby color. Dark, but shows a pure redness in the light. Nice thick layer of foam. Strongly phenolic aroma. Vague fruitiness (dates, persimmon?). Spicy yeastiness. Huge sweet fruitiness. Cherries and maybe strawberries. Even a detectable leafy hoppiness in the finish. Do I maybe even get some chocolate in the finish? Now it seems like chocolate covered cherries. Curious and unique. The aroma becomes somewhat herbal and spicy, maybe minty or more like the crushed leaves of strawberry vines.

Pours a very dark brown with a huge, foamy light brown head.  Smells very sweet.  Molasses, candy sugar, dark malts, and spice come to mind and were all very prevalant.  The flavor seemed a bit young, but was still quite tasty.  Staying with the sweet theme, it had a good amount of holiday spice to it.  I detected a good dose of cinnamon, alot of candy sugar and dark malts, with a mix of some dark fruit in there as well.  Pretty tasty brew.  Not in the Abt 12s league by any means, but I think this could still improve with some age on it.

750 ml Bottle - Another excellent beer from St. Bernard.  Caramel, malt, chocolate aroma.  Fig ,Raisen, chocolate and yeasty flavors with a bit of spice.  Would have rated even higher if the spice were toned down a bit with more malt flavor.

(Rating #100 for this beer) Corked bottle, post PP SAF: Rich mahogany with lasting frothy off-white head and very good lace. The aroma has notes of brown sugar, caramel, fig, cardamom, clove, earthy and slightly vinous esters. The taste has a big malty profile with rich caramel and sugar along with ripened fruit. Herbal and spicy tone throughout the tasting. There is a note of alcohol as is it still young and brash. The mouth feel is medium-bodied with a sticky and warming presence. Perfect for the season, get ya some.
bottle.  mahogony with huge foamyhead.  belgium yeast, rich nutty malts, strong spice aroma.  spice up front.  rich malt backbone.  some dark fruits.  mild pepper.

Bottle purchased and split two ways at Ebeneezers, Lovell Maine.  Dark brown in color with a large tan head.  Aroma of spices, belgian yeast, candi sugar, caramel and chocolate.  Taste is fruity with vinous notes, also has chocolate, rich caramel, rum soaked raisins, and musty yeast.  Medium to full body.  pretty complex, and enjoyable. reminded me alot of their quad.

Bottle from Capones.  Pours turbid deep ruby/brown with 3-finger khaki head.  Aroma of caramel malt, red grapes, plum, chocolate, cherry, candi sugar, brown sugar.  Complex aroma.  Tastes rich, fruity, with red grape, cherry fig, spicy, caberney, vanilla, and an aroma that reminded me of those Fundip multi flavor packs with the vanilla stick.  This one is very nice.

750 ml bottle shared with Ian. Thanks Ian! Pours reddish brown with a big white head. Sour apple, dark fruit, and raisin aroma. Taste is a little bitter more dark fruit and some apple. Nice big carbonation that finishes nice and clean. A winter warmer for sure, very nice.

Bottle - 750mL corked and caged. Pours a dark brown. Bubbly tan head is reduced quickly to spotty lacing. The aroma is very rich and decadent. Dark fruits, soft caramel, light floral notes, soft spice, and yeast. The nose on this is almost mouth-watering. The first sip has some upfront bitterness that smooths out into more caramel, dark fruits, sweet malts, dusty yeast, spices and soft brown sugar notes. The body on this is very bubbly and light-medium to medium. The alcohol is nowhere to be found. Finishes with more yeast and spice notes encircled by candyish notes, sweet malts, and soft caramel. Very tasty!

Bottle (thanks rlgk & larsniclas)  Dark red colour, with a creamy head. Aroma of citrus,yeasty,caramel flowers and a bit sournes in the end(?) Flavor has almost the same, medium to full body long fruity finish.

750mL bottle, courtesy of Brian.  Thanks!  Pours a murky, ruby-tinged color; fluffy, light-tan head with excellent retention and lacing.  Plenty of cloves and spice and esters in the aroma.  Sharp carbonation upfront; chewy esters and brown sugar and dried fruits; very light spice presence; reasonably similar to the 12, with spices and less body.  Lengthy, esters and brown sugar in the finish.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2007 Best By 09/08/2012, Sampled December 2007
Served only lightly chilled, the beer is clearly well carbonated as even a reasonably careful pour produces a billowing, slightly over-flowing, initially seven-finger thick, lightly browned, tan colored head of foam that slowly recedes while leaving a delicate lacing pattern on the sides of my 30cl Tripel Karmeliet tulip.  the beer sits in my glass a burnt, amber tinged, very dark brown color, but shows a brilliantly clear, dark ruby hue when held up to the light.  In passing inspection of the nose, aromas of dark fruit and spices mix quite equally.  A deeper draught of the nose reveals aromas of raisins, figs, concentrated plum, brown sugar, sweet cola, clove, touches of allspice, a hint of molasses, dark chocolate, light ginger or maybe really galangal and even some cardamom like notes.  The aroma ends up being a bit more focused on the dark, caramelized fruit notes with just a backdrop of spice character that leaves no doubt that this is a Belgian yeast strain.

The carbonation provides a prickly, lightening effect to what is really a medium full beer.  It does not drink as heavy as the 10% alcohol might suggest, but is certainly has that Belgian lightness that is in many of the better made strong beers from their.  The beer is definitely sweet, which accentuates the quite noticeable dark fruit character; caramelized plums, figs, raisins and even some apple flavors are individually noticeable.  The beer finishes with a mix of spiciness and warming alcohol that is a touch pepper-like, with some spicy ginger, toasty brandy & rum, and some turpene driven phenolic clove / cardamom notes.  Bread like malt notes reminiscent of toasted bread, hints of browned-whole-grain bread, touches of rye, caramelized-dark German bread, biscuit malt and roasted / broiled / concentrated figs.

The second pour has just as voluminous a head as the first, and the beer, a little more chilled now, tastes even a bit lighter than it did initially.  The ample carbonation focuses the flavors more on the peppery spice notes, while softening the rich fruitiness that is there after it has mellowed.  This is certainly a contemplative brew; I could wish for a bit more malt complexity in the flavor (at times the alcohol and spiciness can be a little too much), but the nose really is quite intriguing.  While I certainly enjoy the lightness / heft of this brew as is, it seems to be missing a bit of richness that could add a bit more balance (these are not necessarily opposing characters though as some richness could be added without making this beer feel heavier).

Purchased: <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Tucson, AZ

Bottle; poured a dark, muddy brown with a large off white head.  Aroma of dark fruit, spice, citrus, alcohol and brown sugar, and bubble gum.  Combination of some assertive flavors (dark fruit, brown sugar and yeast) and some subtle flavors (yeast, alcohol, spice, citrus/melon).  Some could find it overly sweet, but I thought it was well done.  Flavor was seemingly better with each sip.  Delicious beer; top notch winter seasonal.
Bottle.70cl. Sweet and spicy aroma, fine head, malty and alcohol taste a bit sweet, lots of dark fruits.

Bottle: pours a dark redish brown with a long lasting foamy white head, aroma of sweet cherries and maybe some other dark fruit, taste is sweet and dry, my first thought is a less heavy feeling version of the regular St. Bernanrdus,  However, I just drank a Nøgne Ø Dark Horizon First Edition so perhaps this rating isnt as unbiased as I would like.  Good stuff regardless of my drunken state.

Bottle from Kingdom Liquor, FL. Poured hazy brown color with a large fizzy brown head that was mostly lasting with excellent lacing. Aroma was as complex heavy spicy nutmeg and yeast. Medium body with a creamy texture. Heavy spice bittersweet flavor with a heavy bittersweet finish with medium alcohol bite. Good brew.

I have been looking forward to this one. The body is murky medium brown with a large light tan head. The aroma is cinnamon and black cherries. There is also some caramel and brandy. The taste is spicy with some cinnamon and apples. Nice smooth body with plenty of the spices and some mineral notes in the finish. St. Bernardus has another winner in this Christmas brew.

Poured a lightly hazy amber color with a medium sized, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of caramel malts, cinnamon, sugar plums, and a dried fruity note.  Taste of caramel malts, light roast, spices, nuts, and a slightly alcoholic finish.

750ml bottle shared courtesy of weeare138. The cork violently flew off and dented TomDecapolis ceiling before weeare138 even got the metal cage off. The expected gushing never folowed though. Poured a dark and muddy brown color with a very large sized off white head. Aromas of spices, dark fruits, citrus, and yeast. Tastes of spices, dark fruits, and citrus. Light alcohol finish.

Very thick on the palete, nicely carbinated. Darker brown color. Expected it to be more spiced (christmas beer) , but really do enjoy this beers flavor. Fruity dark aroma, similar to la fin du monde but not as light and sweet. Finishes with a sweet alcohol burn. Do i taste a hint of nutmeg? maybe not. Really enjoyed this.

Thanks to weeare138.  Pours a deeper brown with lots of ruby/amber notes and a large bubbly/rocky off white lacing head.  Aroma of citrus, some dark fruits, mixed spices, Belgian spices and yeast, caramel and toffee.  Flavors of the same. Spice are kind of on the lighter side with some peppery notes.

Bottle.  Dark, nutty brown with a nice creamy think head that dissipates a bit.  Fruity spice aroma.  Taste isnt as fruity as it smells and its very bubbly.  Nice dry finish with a sweet alcohol burn.  Nice brew, but not as fully complete as the 12.

Poured from a 750 ml bottle.  Deep mahogany-red pour; greyish skin disseminates slowly.  Varied nuances on the nose thinly veil what seems to be a somewhat empty foundation; orange peel, ginger, juniper, cranberry bread, and almond frosting project loudly.  These, however, are the entire bit, though they would seem to better serve as tangential tones.  Taste is surprisingly sprightly, though still bold; plenty of banana sweetness with clove, spruce, and sweet nuts in dates and young coffee beans.  Lacks depth or any indication of rich quality; this seems to be a simple, lukewarm dubbel at its heart.  Somewhat light in the mouth, sharply carbonated, and again, lacking in core character.  A bit more brawniness of malt would do wonders for it; as is, its rather disappointing, enjoyable as it still is.  Thanks for sharing, Brian!

Bottle.   Pours hazy dark brown nearly black with a dense yellow/beige colored head.   Aroma is dark fruit, cinnamon, spice, alcohol, fig, yeast.   Flavor is chocolate, toffee, cinnamon, figs, raisins, clove, yeast, alcohol.   Palate is medium to full bodied, medium to high carbonation, finishes sweet and slightly hot.   Deelicious!!

750mL bottle, no date.  Mahogany with a rocky three finger beige head, good retention.  Aroma of scorched caramel, figs, sweet raisins, plenty of Belgian yeast, brown sugar, and finishes with a little bit of spice and alcohol.  Flavor has some added tart apples to help keep the sweetness at bay, as well as adding some light toast.  Light warming alcohol is present, but not showing any sign of the 10%.  Semi dry finish with a bitterness peaking around a 2.  Burps figs and brown sugar.  Full body thats lightened by the lively carbonation.  Very good offering from St. Bernardus.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Sharp, tiny carbonation bubbles and finishes with a sweetness. Interesting aroma, some spice. Rated day after to the best of my recollection.

Pours a dark reddish brown with large tan head, and chunky floaters.  Plum, raisin, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, spice, and a bit of chocolate.  Nice and complex, quite tasty.  Personally found it over carbonated though.
750 ml bottle from Wholefoods.  Red copper with a fluffy tan head.  Aroma of Bready Begian yeast and spice.  Sweet caramel and fruit taste, brown sugar and spices.  Decent.

Bottle. WOW! This beer is huge. I know that it is roughly the same alcohol % as the St B 12, but it has a bigger heavier mouthfeel to me, flavor overload. Aroma of dark fruit, cinnamon, spice, and alcohol. The flavor is a complex mix of all said aromas, very "full" tasting, heavy syrupy fruitiness and spice. It is very malty, but has a spice dryness always lingering along with the alcohol presence. This is an awesome Christmas Ale!

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2012

Source: Bullocks

Appearance: opaque dark brown, frothy beige head, lots of scattered and drippy lace
Aroma: rich sweet fruity plum aroma with a touch of spices like a spiced Christmas plum pudding
Body: highly carbonated body in need of decanting
Flavor: rich malt flavor, rich chocolate and dark caramel malt, lots of fruity character enhanced by a touch of sweet caramel, the spicyness comes in to add character and end up adding a drying balance and light earthy bitter finish, the chocolate continues to get richer but is kept in check by the earthyness, the fruityness grows as well but does not pick up the needed sweetness

Aroma: 9/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 17/20

Bottle: I swear every St. Bernardus I have had so far is nothing but a fine and enjoyable treat. This Belgian strong ale lives up to its name; I mean come on the alcohol presence alone can be detected upon aroma and tasting and it would be an understatement to say this really is a strong ale. The appearance was a deep brown hue with a thick development of foam but yet somehow seemed not to be firm or concentrated like other heads formstrange.

wonderful looking beer,as all st. bs beers are.dark brown with a nice foamy light brown head.the nose is a complex mix of belgian yeast,oatmeal cookies,apples,cinnamon,and allspice.the flavor is much of the same with a slight metallic finish.much like the special edition but with more spice.excellent beer from the st. bernard brewery as always.

Bottled.
Deep amber. Large off-white head.
Roasted with toffee and yeasty, fruity aroma.
Spicy and yeasty in flavour too. Medium body with huge maltiness.

Pours dark red-brown with about 3 fingers of light, airy head.  Odor of cinnamon and raisin strong throughout, with hints of other spices.  Plum and raisin sweetness dominates the aftertaste, which starts off smooth, and it all ends with a slight taste of alcohol in the finish.  Another interesting beer from St. Bernardus, and one of their stronger ales.
Reddish brown.  Light airy head but full.  Strong aroma of raisin/plum?  Tastes thick but is smooth with lightish body, just heavy on the tongue.

Cloudy brown pour with a huge and lasting light brown head.  Spicy aroma with some yeast, orange and dark fruit.  Mouthfeel is creamy and nicely carbonated.  Very smooth.  Moderately sweet.  Lots more dark fruit, plum, raisin. Some banana towards the finish.  Slightly hot from the alcohol, but not bad.  Finish is malty, sweet and has lingering alcohol.  Pretty good seasonal.

(750ml bottle) Large beige head atop hazy dark brown body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, fig/date, cinnamon, caramel, light nutmeg.  Taste is moderately sweet, raisin/fig, caramel, cinnamon.  Light alcohol burn but not off-putting.  Medium-full body with some syrup, effervescence.

Bottle (thanks rlgk & larsniclas) shared with a bunch of RB:s. Deep red copper with medium to large fluffy head. Roasted and caramelly malt aroma with spicy and yeasty notes. Medium bodied with soft ´carbonation. Very good balance, with a discrete initial sweetness and a dry finish.

Bottle. Amber color, bigg offwhite head. Malty, spicy aroma, yeasty and with some fruity notes. Yeasty, spicy flavor, fruity, hoppy, grassy, some sweet notes. Malty, sweetish finish,. A heavy x-masbeer.

Bottle at Benny.
Hazy brown with a creamy beige head, nice lacings. Aroma heavy malty (orange, brown sugar, dark fruits). Flavor heavy sweet. Full body. Really nice.

Pours dark brown with a garnet hue and loose sudsy tan head.  The aroma has anise, ginger, cinnamon and nutmeg - very spiced.  There is also light breadiness and earthy yeast.  Medium / full body thats very crisp and has lots of carbonation.  The flavor starts with the spice with a high focus on anise.  There is a lot of heavy malt with alcohol completely unhidden.  The finish shows even more of the abv along with losts of dark fruits and sharpness.  A very nice beer, but may be nicer with age if it takes off a bit of the alcohol bite.

Pours a dark reddish brown, with a huge creamy light tan head.  Nice spicy nose with a powerful anise presence as well as some chocolate, pepper, and a light almost potpouri like orange.  Good dose of alcohol accompanies this full bodied medium carboantion.  Nice spicy anise, raisens, caramel, and a little more of the alcohol warmth accentuates the very light floral hops on the finish.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: Pours a clear cdark brown with a very big lively beige head. Very sweet with spices and oranges. Hint of burnt malts. Also strong alcohol notes. Dry finish with oranges. Too sweet.

Bottle... Murky prune-colored ale with a large, fluffy, off-white head.  Long-lasting tight retention. Boozy, dark fruits (I mean all of them) aroma and flavor with some tawny port thrown in. High alcohol and hop bitterness. Did I say boozy?... HOT! Full-bodied with fizzy carbonation. Alcoholic, sweet dark fruit, almost-salty finish.

Merry Christmas to all of my fellow beer enthusiasts! Just want to give my worthless opinion about this holiday brew. The beer is lovely. Has a nice foamy head(maybe a bit too much but it doesnt hide away too fast), and the caramel brown is awfully nice. Very fruity smell with raisins, reminds me of dark fruits. I also smell figs, and malts. The smell is also accompanied by a strong aroma of alcohol. I was expecting this due to the fact that the Abt 12 has this characteristic. VERY CARBONATED, it sizzles on my tongue. Too carbonated. The flavors are what you would expect, fruit; the raisins and the plums are quite pleasant. The malt smoothness is there and the yeast is slightly noticeable. The beer is great but the carbonation is ridiculous.

750ml bottle. Great aroma. Lots and lots of fruit and yeast. Strawberries, figs, plums, raisins and some dry and quite spicy yeast. Pours opaque brown with deep amber highlights. Big, creamy, frothy head that takes forever to subside. Flavor is mostly dry with touches of the figgy sweetness and dry yeast. Medium bodied with mouth filling carbonation.

Pours opaque, dark brown w/ a tall, semi creamy froth that takes its sweet time to reduce. Superb head retention w/ full, sticky lacework. Brisk aromas of ripe berries, spicey bitters, and bubblegum. Full nectar with the kind of carbonation that needs to be coaxed out but lending to a rich and creamy texture. This brew is intense, forthright, and generous. The flavors come at me like machinegun fire. Bright spicey clove,  cinnamon, and licorice. Ripe melon, plumb, blackcherry, rasin, nectarine, rock minerals, and creamy butter. A  moderate hop profile brings out the spicey character but never overdoing it. The big malty backbone supports the hive allowing everyone to be heard. Its only mildly sweet and very well balanced. This brew says Happy Christmas everytime I take a sip. It really opens up after a bit of warming. Another masterpiece by this magnificent brewery. Highly recommnded.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2008 Bottle from Whole Foods. Pours a dark dirty amber color. Slightly sweet spiced aroma at first. A little more sniffing reveals a slightly earth saison quality. Spiced dark fruity flavors. Long lasting head. Pretty rich, although the alcohol is pretty noticeable. Pretty enjoyable.

Pours a mahogany brown with 2 finger beige  head.  Complex aromas of nutmeg, banana bread, bubblegum, raisins, and spices.  Has Christmas-esque taste to it with its sweet spices.  Quite an array of flavors.  Has the traditional St. Bernard yeast character to it with some added flare.  Sticky sweet.

Bottle. Rich mahogony with a beige head. Big plum and dark fruit aroma with lots of malt and brown sugar. Rich malt and caramel with dark fruit (plum/date) and lots of earthy spice. Malts linger with fruit (and a bit of banana). Nice complexity. Medium body. Carbonation a bit high. Mlats come through more and more. Very nice.

Pours a dark  dark brown with some murky orange highlights and a medium sized off white head. Aroma is malty and caramel with a very distinct strong banana aroma. Flavor is much of the same. Somewhat sweet and chocolate and carmel notes with a hint of spice and lots more of the banana phenolic flavors. Creamy body. Pretty good but hard to drink more than just a glass of this. Maybe just cause i dont dig the banana so much.

Cloudy amber color and big, i mean big white head.  Well spiced and reminds me of past times.  Aroma is floral and fruity with some red fruits in there like cherry.  Flavor is deeper, more like licorice and brown sugar.  You are left with this faint sweetness like you just ate too many christmas cookies.  Nice seasonal here.

Ive never seen a head this huge. Its large-bubbled, beige, and five inches tall and it sits atop an inch and a half of deep brown-red beer. Fortunately, the thing doesnt last too long. As the bubbles pop they release a cola-ish aroma which covers up the huge spice notes I got upon opening the bottle. When theyre done, those spices come back--nutmeg and cinnamon with a touch of cardamom. Theres also a good deal of dark fruit and pronounced brown sugar notes. Good cheer abounds. The flavor is full of spicy yeast and sweet bread, with light candi sugar and cardamom. Alcohol kicks in on the back end, mixing with the spice a bit unpleasantly. The finish calms down with brown sugar. Very good.

Bottle. Used this as an accompaniment to a spareribs stew with spicy paprika. Based on that your mileage may vary.
Pours with some effervescent carbonation and a nice brown color. To my great dismay my wife likes it as much as I do. In any case this is a great beer. It has great flavors of dark fruit, some spicy yeast and some toffees. very supple, rich mouthfeel and finish. This one works also well with cheese.

Shared with Pete Nov 07.  As with other St. Bernardus beers, just too much spice goin on for me.  Aroma is dark malt, toffee, raisins, and a crap load of spice.  Flavor is much the same...  too spicy, hot, young - curious too see how this will develop.  It sure looks top notch though, no surprise there.  The 12 is king!

Sampled at Redlight thanks to boboski. Very generous, thank you Jason! Dark caramel brown body with a light tan head that is medium-large in size. Excellent retention and lacing. Nose of spices - nutmeg, cinnamon - figs, dates, raisins, plums, toffee and malts. Flavor is a bit below the aroma, mainly because iit doesnt mesh that well together at this point. The fruit notes kind of overpower the rest of the beer at this point. Medium bodied, creamy full palate. Finish is lengthy, fruits and spices. As Jason says, this beer tastes pretty young, so I am excited to see what some age will do for it. As it stands it is a very good beer. With some age it could be elite.

750ml. dense and dark brown color with a creamy head. the head is not quite as thick as other st. bern ales. bright fruity nose of apricot and cherry. only a faint hint of the potency reveals itself. good balance of sweet and spicy flavors. big fruity sweetness, never gets sticky. finish has some clove and other spices.

Tasted 11/6/07.  750ml bottle.  Hazy and tapering in color from brown to gold.  From murky to clear.  Spotty bone white head.  Cola and caramel aromas.  Medium to full bodied with lively effervescence.  Spiced and fruity.  Citrus and tight bitterness.  Cloying long yeasty notes.  Apple fruit notes.  Tight and young.  Zippy and good, but not quite enough age to truly meld the flavors.
Bottle: Pours a deep red with a tan head. Aroma, yeasty notes, spice, caramel and brown sugar. Flavor, sweet spices, caramel, chewy mouthfeel, yeasty, some fruits. Nice beer.

750, corked and baled. Uncorks with a heck of a nice pop for a beer that doesnt geyser. Pours nearly black, barely any highlights, just a few hints of brown in the murk. Thick, sudsy head with layers of tiny bubbles like hundreds of spider eggs. Occasional wisps of lace. Nose is a big fat bubble gum and dark fruit runaround; not sure if it could maybe stand to settle down a bit and soften, but its definitely pleasant enough. This IS a festive party beer, after all. Medium-ish body, soft and almost loose but not really watery. Tight carb. Sweet figgy, datey, moist-fruit-bread-y flavors right from the jump and throughout the mid-palate. Fairly clean and light non-sticky candi sugar finish. Pretty good little Xmas beer, though not the absolute best of the bunch.

Bottle: Burnt caramel, large frothy beige head, clumpy lacing.   Sweet candied dark pitted fruit nose, minor licorice.   Some alcohol is noticeable.   Alcohol and minor dark pitted fruit on the tongue.   Unlike many other St Bernardus beers, this one has a sort of hairsprayish alcohol tinge on the tongue.   Not heavy, but its there.   Warming, with dark pitted fruit bringing up the backside.   This to me is like a candy with a delicious outer coating (aroma) but when you get to the center it isnt as tasty (flavorful).   Body and mouthfeel are moderate.   Somewhat of an alcoholic finish.   Not as robust or flavorful as other St Bernardus products, but still decent.   I would say its less flavorful then their Abt12 and certainly more alcoholic.   Good, but not as much depth and certainly more alcoholic.   Aging this may not yield much more flavor, cept maybe less burn.   Anyways, glad to see a new St Berny coming to Seattle.   I just wished we could get their Easter beer.

Tallahassee, Fl. - Market Square Liquors, 750 ml caged corked bottle. Dark chestnut brown with an extremely thick and fluffy khaki colored head, thick, sticky lacing. Strong aroma - hints of bubble gum, rum raisin cake and alcohol. Good rib sticking flavor. Hints of licorice, molasses, raisins,  touch of caramel, hint of booziness in the finish. Very warming and welcome. Good, thickish mouthfeel. Will be a standby at the liquor store this winter when nothing else new to rate.

Reddish brown, fairly large head with really good lacing and retention. Aroma is somewhat similar to Pannepot, I think there is some anise spicing here. Darker fruits, sugar and caramel are here as well. Some heat in the finish, relatively high carbonation light sweetness but mostly dry. Its been a while since Ive had a Bernardus beer, good stuff.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2008 Courtesy redlight. Poured a dark brown with a medium foamy tan head that left behind nice lacing. The aroma was of sweet malts, dark fruits, spices, and yeast. The taste is much the same with the dark fruits, malts, caramel, and yeast flavors coming through. I also got some grapes and figs in there as well. It is medium bodied with a nice creamy mouthfeel with good carbonation that goes down smooth. The alcohol is masked really well. Another solid brew from these guys, that I will have to revisit again closer to christmas.
a full, rich, dark, malty beer. Its got all the quality that a great beer should have. The taste flavors of caramel, spice form just the right mixture of what makes a great christmas beer.

The aroma is fruity and yeasty with malt and spice. The appearance is hazy brown with a huge head. The flavor is like the aroma with an astringent finish. The palate is a little thin but OK. Not what I expected.

Very nice Abbey. Deep brown flavors. Is it all that different from 12? A little...but  because it is not spiced like other Christmas brews, the distinction is not that sharp. Still, a really good beer. Enjoyed it.

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy brown/amber with a large long lasting light tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of yeast spice, caramel, dark fruit, and fresh baked bread. Taste is the same as aroma just not as prominent. Medium creamy mouthfeel from the carbonation but it finishes slightly watery with a mild amount of bitterness. The alcohol is very well hidden. Very good.

Pour is a dark brown with a large tan head.  Aroma is spices and a very creamy bready yeast.  Flavor is dark fruits, spice and a odd licorice taste.  Finish is dry and you really get an alcohol kick at the end.  Quite a tasty beer to keep you warm in the winter months.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2016 The classic St. Bernardus packaging was themed in red and green on this bomber, and the jolly monk had donned a Santa Claus hat as snow covered the brewery shield.  Is this going to really be bringing heavenly nectar within reach as promised?  There was only one way to find out.

The cork came off with a loud pop, but the beer stayed put inside the bomber.  As I poured it into a St. Bernardus goblet, the beer was murky brown in color, and the head was only one finger tall.  The aroma was heavy with anise and had some banana notes as well.  The taste seemed like a watery version of the Abt 12, except it seemed almost salty.  The dark malts seemed to be struggling to rise above the huge carbonation sting.  There were overtones raisins, figs, red apples, and brown sugar, but everything seemed to be diluted with club soda.  The alcohol was well hidden as expected.  There was some earthy yeast flavor in the taste as well.  Id say that this was quite a complex beer, but not all aspects of complexity were working towards a cohesive whole.  As it warmed up some, the carbonation became more subdued, allowing me to appreciate the flavors better.  Medium full mouthfeel was good, but never approached that velvety smoothness of the exceptional quadruples.

A good beer, but pales in comparison with its other illustrious brethren.  Not a fair standard I suppose, since most other beers do as well.

Fruity, malty nose, with subtle hints of spice, probably from the yeast, almost a slight peppermint aroma.  Pours cloudy amber, almost brown.  Smooth and malty, dark fruits, grapes, a slight fig taste, sweet dark malts, finishes with a slight bit, and minty aftertaste.

Bottle: Pours a hazy dark mahogany with a dense, pillowy froth of light tan head.  Aroma of sweet doughy caramel with some bready yeasty notes, slightly floral, earthy hops and some raisins.  Body starts with a fairly thick dark caramel malty sweetness and an earthy bittering hop presence toward a slightly drier finish. Pretty well-balanced, complex and enjoyable.
dark brown with a nice large whipped cream tan head.  dark fruits with hints of licorice and anise.  aroma of raisins, plum.    medium bodied.
Hazy brown with medium off white head. The sweet aroma has overripe fruits, malt and spices. Flavor is malty, sweet and has hints of liquorice. Warming alcohol ends it off.

25 oz bottle, winter 2006 vintage, via sunevdj.  Pours an orangish amber body under a large fluffy craggy beige head that climbed out of my chalice.  Lots of visible carbonation.  The entire glass was covered in a complete curtain of lacing, though Im not sure thats an accurate word to describe a soild covering.  Aroma is typical Belgian Stong Ale, very fruity with lots of yeast influence.  Light raisin and plum, a little brown sugar, and some light alcohol.  The alcohol influence is a little bit much for the flavor.  It doesnt have the depth and complexity of say the St B 12 that can hide that level of alcohol.  Surprisingly thin on flavor even.  Just a light brown sugar and fruitiness up front fading to a slightly yeasty alcohol thinned finish.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied and when let to breathe developed a nice soft carbonation.  A little thinner than I expected.  Save for the alcohol, I think that this had the depth and complexity of flavor that would warrant just calling this a Belgian Ale.  Maybe a little cellar time would tone down the alcohol flavor some.

Big bottle. hazy darkbrown colour with a creamy long lasting off-white head. Aroma of sweet caramel toasted malts, spices and fruits. Lovely flavour of the toasted malts, dark fruits, bitter-sweet spices, hops and.... alcohol. A nice Chritsmas warmer indeed!

Bottled. Dark amber coloured. Unclear. Light brown head. Fruits, light raisin, spice (cloves and cinnamon) in the nose. Flavour of dried fruits, alcohol, spice, ligth cocoa and liqourice. Full bodied. Marcipanny alcoholdense end. Very warming and delicous.
Bottle. Murky orange colour, very small head. Sweet aroma, dried fruit. The flavour is quite sweet with a good level of alcohol to balance.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2016 First ratingRating added 1/5/200775 cl bottle brought home from Denmark.Shady brown color with yeast particles, huge foam settling to a creamy tan head. Lots of CO2, the cork almost killed me... Fresh scent, spicy and some alcohol, sweet as well. Full and also spritzy mouthfeel. Spicy and Belgian ale yeast taste with a warming alcohol feeling.9/33/8/4/17=4.1RerateBig bottle thanks to Rick! Sampled on December 7, 2016.Hazy dark brown color, small tan head. Gingerbread, spicy, banana, alcohol, malty scent. Malty, alcohol, grainy, bitter taste, also spicy. Medium full mouthfeel, medium bitterness. Warming alcohol.Wow, really didnt enjoy this even close to as much as 9 years ago...7/3/4/4/9=2.7

Bottle: Hazy, nut brown body with a nice beige, lasting head and lacings on the glass. Nose of malt, dried fruit, spices and a touch of yeast and alcohol. Balanced sweet flavour with roasted malt and coffee. Medium to full bodied. Alcoholic finish.

Bottle. Characteristic from St. Bernardus is to be found in this one as well, with a slight Christmas spicy feel to it. Reddish brown colour with a big head. Mostly lasting and left some nice lacing. Mouth feel has much more alcoholic appearance then the ABT 12. It is impossible not to compare it with one of my all time favourite beers. Aroma is medium malty with some hops to it. Caramel, liquorish, candies, cinnamon and dry fruit. Medium bodied as it lacks the complexity of its bigger brother. Slightly syrupy texture with a lively carbonation. Medium sweet with a medium sweet finish. Kind of disappointing when you had the ABT 12 to compare it with.

75 cL bottle. Pours muddy brown/amber red with light brown and quickly disappearing head. Aroma is sweet, hops and caramel malt and elements of alcohol. Taste is caramel, fruit, alcohol and malts. Beer is slightly over-carbonated, might however be a good thing for the heavy x-mas food. Does not have a complex taste and after-taste as the description indicates. Ordinary belgian x-mas ale.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is dark amber. Aroma and taste are dominated by cinnamon and orange. Sour sweet. Nice!

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2010 Re-rating after KBF 09. Quite sweet with a light bitterness and loads of cinnamon. Lots. Takes a great classic and ruins it with too much spice. Old rate: Last gulps from the last bottle of it at the Kerstbierfestival in Essen. I had high expectations, since the St. B 12 is one of my all-time favorites. But here I was disappointed. Its lighter, clearer, much less complex in flavor. Its dominant, saving trait is a spiciness. Decently bitter finish, notable alcohol. Little malt. Maybe there is a reason they didnt want to sell it in Belgum... Glad I could try it, anyway.
Bottle. Clear brownish colour with a huge mostly lasting of white head. Rich aroma and taste of malts, fruits and spices with a alcoholic finish. good, but strong.

Good, but shortlived yellow head over dark-mahogany beer. Nuts, peanuts, alcohol & fusels, and some caramel-like sweetness, but fading out. Sweet taste, with a hint at sourish fruitiness. Dark malts, dark - nearly outfermented - candi sugar, and some fatty acids in the finish. Very full-bodied, alcohol in the retronasal build-up. Basically quite good, but not overwhelming beer. St. Bernard is a brewery that, IMO, does it regular beers better than its specials.

Bottle: I feel honored off the bat as the first none person from Denmark to rate this thanks to Kerstbierfestival! It pored a hazy dark brown with a creamy off white head, The aroma was fruity and complex spice. It finished similar with fruit and a dry tangy spice/alcohol zip.
Bottle. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Amber colour. Powerfull complex spicey aroma and flavor. Long finish. Creamy palate. Nice beer but not my favorite belgian christmasbeer.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is dark amber. Aroma and taste are dominated by cinnamon and orange. Sour sweet.

(Bottle 75 cl) Hazy, nutty brown with a tall, creamy, off-white head leaving a pretty lacework. Vinous, port-like aroma with notes of dried fruit. Quite a full and rich body with lightly sweet, dark malt accents. Touches of yeast and a lot of dried fruit. Never gets overly sweet. Quite a complex brew. 081206

Bottle. Very small and surprisingly low white head. Beer too cold maybe. Hazy dark brown body. Dry and spciy barley malt aroma (promising). Quite sweet actually, flavor interesting though with raisins, plums, caramel and maybe juniper berries. Alcohol percentage well hidden. Liquorice - sorry no, mates.
Bottle at Dæmningen 37 - shared with Karen, Henning & Mette. Dark brown - offwhite head. Yeast, raisins, licorice, hop, spicy, burning tongue feeling.

@ Horsens Ølfestival 2006. Muddy deep amber colour with a tan head. Sweet malty aroma with a spicy and fruity note. Malty, dark fruit sweet flavor with notes of liqourice. Dry and light alcohol sweet finish.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2007 Raised numbers at 2007 re-rating. Muddy red brown with a big off-white head. Malt and yeast aroma with caramel and a hint of spice, cinnamon and vanilla. Complex spicy-fruity flavour, sweet but with a licorice-y dryness. Too fizzy for my taste, but if its designed for the Danish market, that might be a clever move. Less fizzy in 2007?

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2014 Draught.
Hazy orange brown coloured with an off white head.
Aroma of fruits, spices and caramel.
Flavour of fruits, spices and caramel.
Fizzy palate.
Bottle. Red brown colour with a small beige head. Sweet malty, dark fruits aroma and taste. Medium body with a sweet light alcoholic finish.

Bottle. Dark reddish brown color with a nice huge white head. Yeast at the bottom. Nice aroma of dried fruit, yeast and a little notes of spices. Flavour is nice with notes of spices, yeast and  with a warm feeling from the alcohol in the finish.

Brown body with a red shine, big bubbled beige head, laces; Big fresh fruity nose with lots of ripe, warm red berries and fresh nuts, very well balanced; Very big bubbled huge carbonation, freshly bitter; Looong fruity finish, well balanced with a fine bitterness. Very, very good beer.
Red-brown with little head. Spicy aroma with alcohol tones. Sweet with caramel flavours and lots of complex cinnamon-based spicyness.
Dark brown color. Spicy aroma of dried fruit. Flavour with notes of spices, yeast and ends up with a warm feeling from the alcohol. Boring christmas beer.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2012 Brown and unclear. Beige head, medium lasting. Spicy aroma, mint, cardamon. Lactic-acid notes. Too sharp and unpleasent. Rerate: Aged a couple of years, much more harmonic now. Aroma of faint spice and herbs, a lot of different ones, almost harmonic. Flavor is mainly sweet. More spice. Some mint, grain.

75 cl bottle. Yeast at the bottom. Dark reddish brown colour with a nice huge white head. Nice aroma of dried fruit, yeast and a little touch of spices. Pretty nice flavour with notes of spices, yeast and ends up with a warm feeling from the alcohol, but the alcohol are very low representing at the same time.
